LeadPara.Para: Foundrae, the fine jewelry line Beth Bugdaycay launched with her husband, Murat, in 2015, is all about the mix. Wearers stack rings, pair enameled charms and create custom, 18-karat gold pieces that pull from the brand's 60-strong lexicon of symbols -- a triangle for transformation, a lion's head for strength, a Bowen knot for true love. Foundrae's first store, at 52 Lispenard Street in downtown Manhattan, takes a similarly eclectic approach: An antique roll-top jeweler's bench (where shoppers can see items get soldered) and a suite of 1970s-era rounded leather armchairs by Giancarlo Piretti for Castelli sit alongside contemporary pieces such as a moody, eight-by-ten-foot landscape painted by Tyler Hays of the furniture company BDDW. ''To me it's totally Hudson River Valley,'' says Bugdaycay, a longtime admirer of American arts and crafts.

TailParas.Para: (Before she was a designer, she was a kid growing up in the border town of Brownsville, Tex., and paying close attention to her parents, who made traditional rocking chairs.)

The Bugdaycays bought the TriBeCa building -- a long-abandoned cast-iron warehouse built in 1867 -- three years before starting the brand, with the intention of converting it to a townhouse that they would then sell. Beth was still working as CEO of the ready-to-wear label Rebecca Taylor, but feeling, she says, ''ready to start a new chapter.'' And so she, Murat and their two children moved in themselves, leaving room on the ground floor for Foundrae's offices and an eventual store. ''It was a lifestyle decision that gives us access to our family,'' says Murat. ''The kids come after school to give us hugs and say 'Hi.''' That homey quality is apparent in the public space as well. There are even shelves lined with books, including those by 20th-century American writer Jessamyn West, Bugdaycay's ancestor, that visitors can borrow. Nearby is a weighty 1930s dictionary in which a young Bugdaycay was made to look up words, and a playful sculpture by the London-based artist Stephane Godec that shows a young girl in danger of sleepwalking off the edge of a cliff made of books. ''People use our pieces to tell their own stories,'' says Bugdaycay, who has seemingly inherited an instinct for narrative. ''In my former role, I got so removed from the customer. With this, you end up being friends with everyone.''

Certainly the store marks the latest chapter in Foundrae's story. Next, Bugdaycay will release a line of men's pieces (oversized signets, slinky guard chains) for fall, and a new set of symbols is due for 2019. Among the jewelry that she wears on a daily basis is a medallion with a five-pointed star, the Foundrae symbol for dream. ''But there's also an arrow,'' she says, ''for action. The idea is to dream forward.''
